Place engine log book, log sheets and other relevant papers to be shipped with engine, in a waterproof envelope and seal with pressure sensitive tape (PWC05-069). Place this material in box and place in shipping container. Secure with pressure sensitive tape.
Raise engine using sling (PWC66106) (1).
25077: Make sure safety cover (27) is installed.

Remove LH or RH mount pad cover as applicable, and install LH and RH mount brackets (7 and 19) on intermediate case using four bolts (5) and washers (6) supplied. Tighten 350 to 475 lb.in. (48.0-53.7 Nm) and install lockwire (PWC05-089).
Assemble LH front engine support (12) to LH mount bracket (7) on intermediate case, using pin (4), washer (8) and cotterpin (9).
Install adjustable rods (21) on lugs of exhaust case using pins (24), washers (23) and cotterpins (22).
Install humidity indicator (Ref. IPC) into envelope such that it can be aligned with window in container sleeve.
USE CARE TO ENSURE FUEL/OIL HEAT EXCHANGER IS NOT DAMAGED WHEN INSTALLING ENGINE IN CRADLE.Lower engine into cradle.
Attach LH front engine support (12) to cradle with four bolts (10) and washers (11). Tighten 720 to 800 lb.in. (80-90 Nm).
Install quick release pin (13) to secure RH front support and install lockwire (PWC05-089).
Adjust length of adjustable rods (21) as necessary to locate in rear engine supports (20).
Verify proper thread engagement of adjustable rods by inserting a piece of lockwire (PWC05-089) into inspection holes. The wire must not pass through.
Tighten nut (25), if rods were adjusted, 275 to 300 lb.in. (32-34 Nm).
Install quick release pins (26) in rear engine supports (20) and install lockwire (PWC05-089).
Disconnect sling from engine.
Tie 12 bags of desiccant (Ref. IPC) to the engine, evenly distributed along length of engine.
Evacuate and heat seal engine envelope. Fold envelope to align humidity indicator (Ref. IPC) with window on fiberboard container.
Install fiberboard sleeve over engine. Close and seal sleeve flaps with pressure sensitive tape (PWC05-070).
Install fiberboard cover and seal with pressure sensitive tape (PWC05-070).
Strap container with two horizontal and three vertical sets of ¾ inch steel strapping (PWC05-063) and fit 20 corners, as applicable.

subpara.title: General
subpara.para: NOTE 1: The following preservation/depreservation requirements are highly recommended. The non-compliance to these procedure for a subject engine requires a review of circumstances and engine condition by P&WC before returning the engine in service. Depending on circumstances, recommendations aimed at ensuring serviceability of the engine, may range from a field-level work scope to an engine shop.

NOTE 2: The review of the circumstances will require the operator to provide a letter or other documents to the Customer First Center containing the following information for each engine:
Customer and/or operator,
Engine type and S/N,
Engine TTSN and TCSN,
Average daily usage before engine preservation,
Geographical area where the engine has operated before preservation,
Type of preservation schedule (If any),
Atmospheric conditions in which the engine was stored (air temperature, relative humidity),
Details on how the engine was preserved or if was not preserved at all,
Elapsed time after engine preservation limit,
Any other information susceptible of determining the condition of the engine.

Fuel system preservation can only be done when the engine is installed on the aircraft (or test cell), because activation of the metering valve in the HMU can only be achieved by a powered up EEC. It is therefore recommended that any engine that will be removed from the aircraft for heavy maintenance, with the possibility of being returned to an overhaul facility, be preserved in accordance with the procedure below.

The procedure to be followed for the preservation of engines in service depends on the period of inactivity and whether or not the engine may be rotated during the inactive period (engines installed in aircraft only). The expected period of inactivity should be established and reference made to the Engine Preservation Schedule.For engines inactive for more than 28 days preservation done must be recorded in the engine log book and on tags secured to the engine.

An engine can be stored outdoors for up to 14 days or in a hangar for up to 28 days with standard engine covers. No engine log book entry is required. Standard engine covers must be installed as soon as practical when the aircraft is parked to prevent excessive wind milling, ingress of foreign objects and formation of water/ice.
A hangar is defined as an enclosed area that will protect the aircraft/engines from the elements and is not susceptible to rapid temperature fluctuations.

Standard engine and power plant covers and plugs will not provide an appropriate seal to practically maintain a consistent humidity of 40% with desiccants for extended periods of time. Special storage equipment (example - foil cover) may be required that provides a sealed environment, observation windows, prevent water ingress and make sure adequate water drainage can take place. These are readily made or are available from third party suppliers.

It is important, but not mandatory, that a desalination wash (Ref. Chapter 71-00-00, POWERPLANT - CLEANING) must be done before storage if the engine has been exposed to salt laden environment without a subsequent wash. Make sure that the engine is dried completely with an engine run with aircraft bleeds closed before storage.

procedure.title: Preservation
procedure.note: The best method to maintain an engine is to run it at least once every 14 days between GI and 80% power until the oil temperature reached minimum of 70°C (158°F) for 10 minutes. These engine runs must be logged in the engine log book. For engines inactive for more than 14 days follow the preservation schedule below.
Refer Para. for an alternate method.
procedure.step: The following engine preservation schedule lists procedures to be followed: UNDER NO CIRCUMSTANCES SHOULD PRESERVATIVE OIL BE SPRAYED INTO COMPRESSOR OR TURBINE ENDS OF ENGINES. DIRT PARTICLES DEPOSITED ON BLADES AND VANES COULD ADHERE AND ALTER THE AIRFOIL SHAPE, ADVERSELY AFFECTING ENGINE EFFICIENCY.1 to 14 days - Engines may be left in an inactive state (stored outside), with no preservation protection, . In conditions of wind, rain, snow or ice, inlet and tail pipe covers must be installed. This will prevent too much windmilling and ingress of foreign objects and rain or snow. 15 to 28 days - Engine inactive for up to 28 days and not stored in a hangar (stored outside), must be stored in a sealed environment.. Humidity control is maintained by placing desiccant bags and humidity indicator on wooden racks in engine exhaust duct. Suitable windows must be provided in exhaust closure to facilitate observation of humidity indicators. The cowl drain holes must be free of blockage (Ref. AMM). 1 to 28 days - Engines can be left in an inactive state, provided they are stored in a hangar. It is recommended that engine covers must be installed for added protection. 29 to 90 days - Engine inactive for a period exceeding 28 days, but less than 90 days, must have fuel system preserved (Ref. step (2) following), engine intake and exhaust opening covered, and desiccant bags and humidity indicators installed. 91 days and over - Engines inactive 91 days and more in airframe, or removed for long term storage in container, must, in addition to 29 and 90 day procedures, have engine oil drained. Remove cover plates from unused accessory drive pads and spray exposed surfaces and gearshafts with engine oil(PWC03-001). Replace cover plates.

row.entry: Install Engine Covers or Seal Engine (Ref. Note 1)
Apply Oil to AGB and Intercase (Ref. Note 2)

entry.note: The cowl drain holes must be free of blockage.
Refer to Para. Step .
Stored inside a hangar.
Applicable if engine has been exposed to a salt laden environment and not subsequently washed.

procedure.step:
Carry out preservation of engine fuel system (engine inactive for more than 28 days) as follows:
EXTREME CARE MUST BE TAKEN TO PREVENT FOREIGN MATERIAL FROM BEING DRAWN INTO ENGINE FUEL SYSTEM. EQUIPMENT MUST BE SUPPLIED WITH SUITABLE FILTERS NO COARSER THAN 10 MICRON RATING.Close airframe supply and disconnect fuel inlet supply to fuel pump. Remove four bolts and disconnect primary and secondary fuel lines from fuel dump valve inlet and discard preformed packings. Install suitable flexible line from each tube to drain into an open waste container. Connect preservative oil (PWC05-077) supply line to fuel pump inlet. Inject preservative oil at a pressure of 30 to 60 psig (207 to 414 kPa) and a temperature of 16°C (60°F).
OBSERVE STARTER MOTOR OPERATING LIMITS.Perform a 30 second wet motoring run (Ref. 71-00-00, ADJUSTMENT/TEST), except do not use airframe fuel boost pump. Make sure preservative oil is flowing from both fuel lines into waste container. Repeat if necessary. Turn off preservative oil supply and reduce supply pressure to 0 psig. Drain preservative oil from fuel filter housing by removing drain plug at bottom of housing. Lubricate new preformed packing with engine oil (PWC03-001), install preformed packing on drain plug and install drain plug in fuel filter housing. Tighten 65 to 75 lb.in. (7.5-8.5 Nm) and install lockwire (PWC05-089). Lubricate new preformed packings with engine oil (PWC03-001), install preformed packings on primary and secondary fuel lines and install on fuel dump valve. Install two bolts at each line, tighten 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.0-4.6 Nm). Disconnect preservative oil supply line from fuel pump inlet and cap to avoid entry of contaminants. Check for external preservative oil leaks. Tag engine and power control lever in aircraft cabin, as applicable, with a warning prohibiting cranking of engine and include date of preservation of engine.

procedure.title: Depreservation
procedure.step: Depreservation Schedule 0 to 14 days - No depreservation required. 15 to 28 days - Desiccant and moisture barriers must be removed. Ensure that all previously sealed engine openings are reopened and are unobstructed. 29 to 90 days - Remove engine intake and exhaust covers together with desiccant and humidity indicators. Depreserve engine fuel system. 91 days and over - Engine must be completely depreserved and lubrication system serviced.

For engines preserved for 91 days and over, replace the following AGB seals.
Hydraulic pump gearshaft lip seal (Ref. 72-60-00, ACCESSORY GEARBOX - MAINTENANCE PRACTICES)
Permanent magnet alternator lip seal (Ref. 72-60-00, ACCESSORY GEARBOX - MAINTENANCE PRACTICES)
Alternator lip seal (Ref. 72-60-00, ACCESSORY GEARBOX - MAINTENANCE PRACTICES)
Starter lip seal (Ref. 72-60-00, ACCESSORY GEARBOX - MAINTENANCE PRACTICES)
Breather lip seal (Ref. 72-60-00, ACCESSORY GEARBOX - MAINTENANCE PRACTICES)

Depreservation Procedure Fill engine oil tank with approved oil (Ref. Para. Oil System Filling). The lubricating oil system does not require any depreservation procedures. Remove four bolts and disconnect primary and secondary fuel lines from fuel dump valve inlet and discard preformed packings. Install suitable flexible line from each tube to drain into an open waste container. Connect airframe fuel supply to fuel pump inlet. OBSERVE STARTER MOTOR OPERATING LIMITS.Perform a 30 second wet motoring run (Ref. 71-00-00 ADJUSTMENT/TEST) and ensure clean airframe supplied fuel is flowing from both fuel lines. Repeat if necessary, momentarily selecting TLA from idle to CUT-OFF detents to assist in fuel system purging. Install new preformed packings on primary and secondary fuel lines and install on fuel dump valve. Secure with bolts at each line, tighten and torque 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.0-4.6 Nm). Check for external leaks.

Do engine ground run checks 1, 2 and 3 (Ref. 71-00-00, POWERPLANT - ADJUSTMENT/TEST). For engine inactive for more than 91 days, run the engine for 25 minutes, starting with five minutes at idle, followed by five minutes at 80%, five minutes at 70%, five minutes at 60% and ending with five minutes at idle. Check for oil leakage and oil consumption.

procedure.title: Regular Operation as Alternative to Preservation of Inactive Engines
procedure.step: For engines installed on aircraft, running the engine once in two weeks (14 days) is an acceptable alternative to avoid the preservation procedure given above. This prevents stagnation of fuel in the fuel system, reduces humidity and condensation accumulation in the oil system.

For engines installed on aircraft, running the engine every 28 days for period of six month or more will require the following maintenance activities before returning to active services. Depreservation procedure as per Para. Service the engine as per Para. Do a dry motoring run. Check for oil leakage and correct as necessary. Run the engine for 25 minutes, starting with five minutes at idle, followed by five minutes at 80%, five minutes at 70%, five minutes at 60% and ending with five minutes at idle. Check for oil leakage and oil consumption.

procedure.title: Removal
procedure.step: If engine will be inactive for 29 to 90 days, or is being sent for overhaul, preserve fuel system (Ref. Para. ). If engine is being removed for installation into another aircraft, or moved from one side of an aircraft to the other, fuel system preservation is not necessary.
Drain oil system (Ref. Para. ).
Download EDU data with GBS cable (PWC61969), PW30X Transfer Module P/N 30B2977 (Ref. 77-40-01, ENGINE DIAGNOSTIC UNIT (EDU) - MAINTENANCE PRACTICES).
Remove the powerplant from the airframe (Ref. AMM).
Remove equipment from engine (Ref. AMM).
Install engine in storage container (Ref. Para. ) or maintenance stand (Ref Para. ) as applicable.
If engine is being stored in a container, complete preservation according to preservation schedule (Ref. Para. )

procedure.title: Installation
procedure.step: Remove engine from storage container (Ref. Para. ) or maintenance stand (Ref Para. ) as applicable.
Build up powerplant (Ref. AMM).
Install powerplant in airframe (Ref. AMM).

Depreserve engine fuel system (Ref. Para. ) if necessary. If engine was removed for installation into another aircraft, or moved from one side of an aircraft to the other, fuel system depreservation is not necessary.
Load aircraft S/N and engine position, LH or RH, into EDU with GBS cable.
Do engine checks 1, 2 and 3.
Check engine oil level and replenish as necessary (Ref. Para. ).
Check engine for oil and fuel leaks.
Do engine Check No. 4 (Ref. Chapter 71-00-00, ADJUSTMENT/TEST).

n-para.title: Removal/Installation of Engine from/in Maintenance Stand

procedure.title: Removal (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: Install sling (PWC66106), straps (PWC60181) and chain hoist on the engine and take up the weight.

DO NOT LET ENGINE CONTACT ANY PART OF ENGINE STAND WHEN RAISING.Remove four bolts (4) from lower support bracket (PWC63470) and four bolts (5) from upper support bracket (PWC63469) and remove the engine.
If engine is to be installed in an aircraft determine if engine is to be LH or RH installation.
Relocate oil filler neck (Ref. Para. ) if necessary.
Relocate engine mounts and mount pad covers (Ref. Para. ) if necessary.
Relocate rear engine mount (Ref. Para. ) if necessary.

procedure.title: Installation (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: Make sure the wheels on stand (1) (PWC66300) or (PWC40453) are locked.

DO NOT LET ENGINE CONTACT ANY PART OF ENGINE STAND WHEN LOWERING.Lift the engine with sling (PWC66106), straps (PWC60181) and chain hoist and position on maintenance stand (1) (PWC66300) or (PWC40453). Bolts (6 and 7) on support brackets (2) and (3) must be finger tight.
Install lower support bracket (2) (PWC63470) with four bolts (4). Tighten finger tight.
Install upper support bracket (3) (PWC63469) with four bolts (5). Tighten finger tight.
Torque bolts (4, 5, 6 and 7) 275 to 300 lb.in. (31-33 Nm).
Remove the sling.

n-para.title: Conversion of Engine for LH or RH Installation
n-para.note: Left hand or right hand installation of the engine on the aircraft may require relocation of the following hardware.

procedure.title: Relocation of Oil Filler Neck (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.caution: WHEN RELOCATING OIL FILLER NECK FROM ONE SIDE TO THE OTHER, IT IS VERY IMPORTANT THAT THE OIL LEVEL SENSOR BE POSITIONED PROPERLY, APPROXIMATELY 25° AFT, TO AVOID DAMAGE FROM ADJACENT AIRFRAME STRUCTURE
procedure.step: Drain oil (Ref. Para. , ) until it is below level of filler neck connection at intermediate case.
Remove tube coupling nuts from elbow (1).
Remove bolts (5) fastening the vent tube (2) to the pressure indicator housing (7).
Remove nut (32) and bolt (4), fastening loop clamp (3) to bracket (30).
Remove vent tube (2). Remove and discard preformed packing (6).
Remove filler cap (10). Remove and discard preformed packing (11).

Remove nut (31), bracket (30), washer (29) and bolt (28) from flange C. Remove nut, washers and bolt from similar location on the other side of the engine, approximately 1 o'clock, and install in hole vacated by removal of bolt (28). Torque nut 27 to 30 lb.in. (3.1-3.4 Nm).

Remove bolt (9) fastening bracket (8) and pressure indicator housing (7) to flange. Remove bolt and washer from similar location, approximately 2 o'clock, on other side of the engine, and install bolt and washer in hole vacated by removal of bolt (9). Torque bolt 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.1-4.5 Nm).
25164 or 25206: Remove bolts (13) fastening filler neck (14) to pressure indicator housing (7). Remove pressure indicator housing (7) from filler neck (14). Remove and discard preformed packing (12).

25164 or 25206: Remove two bolts (41), pressure indicator housing (7) from vent tube (36). Remove two bolts (37), fastening vent tube (36). Remove bolt (33), nut (39) and loop clamp (34). Remove vent tube (36). Remove and discard preformed packing (38 and 40).
Remove bolts (22) fastening bottom of filler neck (14) to case.
25164 or 25206: Remove bolts (16) and bracket (15). Remove filler neck (14).
25164 or 25206: Remove bolts (16), bracket (15) and bracket (35). Remove filler neck (14).
Remove bolts (19), washers (18) and blanking plate (17) from the similar location on the other side of the engine, approximately 3 o'clock, and install in spot vacated by removal of filler neck (14).
Remove bolts (24), washers (25) and cover (26) from the similar location on other side of the engine, at approximately 5 o'clock. Remove and discard preformed packing (27).
Lubricate new preformed packing (27) with engine oil (PWC03-001), and install on cover (26).
Install cover (26) with washers (25) and bolts (24), in spot, approximately 8 o'clock, vacated by removal of filler neck. Torque bolts 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.1-4.5 Nm).

25164 or 25206: Lubricate new preformed packings (12 and 23) with engine oil (PWC03-001), and install on each end of the filler neck (14). Install filler neck assembly on opposite side of the intermediate case with bolts (22) at the lower end, and bracket (15) and bolts (16) at the upper end. Torque bolts (22 and 16) 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.1-4.5 Nm). Install the pressure indicator housing (7) on the filler neck tube extension with bolts (13). Tighten the bolts with fingers.

25164 or 25206: Lubricate new preformed packing (23) with engine oil (PWC03-001) and install on the filler neck (14). Install filler neck assembly on opposite side of the intermediate case with bolts (22) at the lower end and bracket (15), bracket (35) and bolts (16) at the upper end. Torque bolts (22 and 16) 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.1-4.5 Nm). Lubricate new preformed packing (38 and 40) with engine oil (PWC03-001) and install on vent tube (36). Install the pressure indicator housing (7) on oil vent tube with bolts (41 and 37). Tighten the bolts with fingers. Install loop clamp (34) with bolt (33) and nut (39). Torque the bolt 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.1-4.5 Nm).
Position bracket (8) and pressure indicator housing (7) on flange C with bolt (9). Torque bolt 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.1-4.5 Nm).

Lubricate new preformed packing (6) with engine oil (PWC03-001), install on vent tube (2) and install tube on the pressure indicator housing (7) with two bolts (5). Torque bolts (5) 24 to 36 lb.in. (2.7-4.1 Nm).
25164 or 25206: Torque bolts (13) 24 to 36 lb.in. (2.7-4.1 Nm).
25164 or 25206: Torque bolts (5, 37 and 41) to 36 - 40 lb.in. (4.1-4.5 Nm).
Lubricate preformed packing (11) with engine oil (PWC03-001) and install on filler cap (10).
Install filler cap (10).
Install elbow (1) on tube, and reposition to connect vent tube (2) . Torque coupling nuts 90 to 100 lb.in. (10-11 Nm) and install lockwire (PWC05-089).
Install bracket (30) on flange C, approximately 1 o'clock, with bolt (28), washer (29) under head, and nut (31). Torque nut 27 to 30 lb.in. (3.1-3.4 Nm).
If removed, install loop clamp (3) on vent tube (2), and fasten to bracket (30) with bolt (4) and nut (32). Torque nut 27 to 30 lb.in. (3.1-3.4 Nm).
Loosen bolts (21), and turn oil level sensor (20) approximately 25° to rear. Lubricate bolts (21) with engine oil (PWC03-001). Torque bolts 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.1-4.5 Nm).
Replenish oil (Ref. Para. , )

procedure.title: Relocation of Engine Mounts and Mount Pad Covers (Ref. Fig. )

figure.title: Engine Mounts and Mount Pad Covers - Relocation

procedure.step: Remove engine mounts from the one and four o'clock position, RH side or the ten and eight o'clock position, LH side, as applicable (Ref. Aircraft Maintenance Manual).
Remove bolts (3), washers (2) and mount pad covers (1) from the one and four o'clock position, RH side or the ten and eight o'clock position, LH side as applicable.
Install engine mounts at the one and four o'clock position or the ten and eight o'clock position as applicable (Ref. Aircraft Maintenance Manual).
Lubricate bolts (3) with engine oil (PWC03-001).
Install mount pad covers (1) with washers (2) and bolts (3) at the one and four o'clock positions, or the ten and eight o'clock positions as applicable.
Torque bolts (3) 36 to 40 lb. in., eight places, LH side or RH side, as applicable

procedure.title: Rear Engine Mount
procedure.step: Relocate the rear engine mount in accordance with Removal/Installation procedure (Ref. 72-70-01, MAINTENANCE PRACTICES).

title.xref: Engine Mounts and Mount Pad Covers - Relocation

general.para: Hot Section Inspection intervals, Engine Operating Time between Overhauls and Periodic Inspections are summarized in Chapter 5-20-00. Detailed inspection procedures are provided, where applicable, in the relevant INSPECTION/CHECK sections of subject chapters in this manual.

consumables.para: The consumable materials listed below are used in the following procedures.

special-tools.para: The special tools listed below are used in the following procedures.

fixtures-and-equipment.para: The fixtures, equipment and supplier tools listed below are used in the following procedures.

row.entry: Everest Digital Borescope - Model PXDL-515 (or equivalent from another manufacturer)
Everest Digital Borescope - Model PXDL-420 (or equivalent from another manufacturer)
Side Viewing Lens - P/N PXT480SG (or equivalent from another manufacturer)

n-para.title: Corrosion
n-para.para: High temperature alloy corrosion may be identified as metal loss or pitting, but more usually appears as local swelling or buildup due to greater volume occupied by nickel oxides. These corrosion products vary in color from black to green and in the advanced state there will be cracking and flaking, referred to as exfoliation. Care should be taken to distinguish between corrosion buildup and possible light brown or rust-colored deposits which are essentially harmless combustion by-products. The latter are usually more widespread over hot section components and, while possibly affecting performance, will not directly affect compressor mechanical integrity.

n-para.title: Engine Overtemperature
n-para.para: Refer to Chapter 5-10-00.

n-para.title: Engine Overspeed
n-para.para: Refer to Chapter 5-10-00.

n-para.title: Engine Immersion in Water
n-para.para: Overhaul engine.

n-para.title: Engine Dropped During Handling
n-para.para: Overhaul engine.

procedure.title: General
procedure.step: The HSI procedure is broken down into major tasks as listed below. The tasks are arranged in accordance with the A.T.A.100 Chapter/Section/Subject numbering system and correspond with the same numbering system in the Illustrated Parts Catalog. Special tools and consumable materials required to do each major task are listed with the appropriate section.
Inspection criteria for individual components which have been removed from the engine are provided in these sections. Refer to Borescope Inspection for inspection criteria of the complete engine.

procedure.title: Summary of HSI Disassembly Procedures
procedure.step: Disconnect No. 4 bearing pressure and scavenge oil tubes from exhaust case (Ref. 79-20-03 and 79-20-04).
Disconnect emergency fuel shut-off cable (Ref. 73-10-05).
Disconnect and remove T4.5 “IN” wiring harness connections from N1/T4.5 terminal box (Ref. 77-20-01).
Remove exhaust case (Ref. 72-50-03).
Remove LP turbine module (Ref. 72-50-02).

Remove HP turbines (Ref. 72-50-01). The first and second-stage HP turbines comprise a balanced assembly. Rejection of either turbine requires that both be returned to an approved overhaul facility for refurbishment and rebalancing, as required.
Remove the first-stage HP turbine vane (Ref. 72-40-01).
Visually inspect the combustion chamber outer case and liner. Remove only if required by the inspection criteria.

procedure.title: Summary of HSI Inspection Criteria
procedure.step: Refer to Table for HSI inspection criteria.

row.entry: Cracks, nicks and dents. Coating loss, sulfidation and honeycomb seal disbonding. Evidence of isolated heat spots. Flange deformation. Clinch nut condition.
Cracks, nicks, dents. Signs of coating loss and sulfidation. Condition of honeycomb seal. Condition of seal retaining rivets.
Cracks, nicks and dents. Condition of internal spline. Evidence of fretting.
Cracks, nicks and dents. Cracked or deformed blade retaining rivets.
Cracks, nicks, dents and security of balance counterweights.
Front and Rear HP Turbine Covers(Ref. 72-50-01)
Cracks, nicks and dents. Damaged knife edge seals. Cover deformation. Blocked or damaged cooling holes.
Cracks in blades. Signs of coating loss. Condition of cooling holes.
Cracks, nicks, dents and security of balance counterweights.
Cracks in blades. Signs of coating loss. Condition of cooling holes.
Cracks, nicks, dents and blocked cooling holes.
Cracks, nicks, dents and blocked cooling holes.
Visual check for condition of accessible harnesses and security of connectors.
Damage, cracks and honeycomb seal disbonding.
Cracks and buckling. Evidence of erosion, metal pick-up or heavy rubs.
First and Second-stage Shroud Retaining Rings(Ref. 72-50-01)
Damage fretting or wear. Radial clearance and gaps when installed.
Inner and Outer First-stage Vane Shrouds(Ref. 72-50-01)
Crack and distortion. Damage fretting or wear on faces. Radial clearance and gaps when installed.
Cracks nicks and dents. Loose worn or damaged interstage turbine seal. Front and rear housing attaching rivets.
Cracks, distortion, fretting, hot spots, carbon buildup. Clean as required.
General condition, functionality and resistance check.
Emergency Fuel Shut-off Valve, Cable and Linkage (Ref. 73-10-05)
Freedom of movement and condition of cable and linkage. Dimensional inspection of fuel shut-off valve.

procedure.title: Summary of HSI Assembly Procedures
procedure.step: Assemble acceptable or replaced hot section components in accordance with the appropriate Chapter/Section/Subject.
Install combustion chamber outer case and liner (Ref. 72-40-01).
Install HP turbine (Ref. 72-50-01).
Install LP turbine module (Ref. 72-50-02).
Install exhaust case (Ref. 72-50-03).
Install T4.5 “IN” wiring harness connections on N1/T4.5 terminal box (Ref. 77-20-01).
Install No. 4 bearing pressure and scavenge oil tubes on exhaust case (Ref. 79-20-03 and 79-20-04).
Connect N1 speed probe wiring harness to N1/T4.5 terminal box (Ref. 77-20-01).
Install and rig emergency fuel shut-off cable (Ref. 73-10-05).
Service oil system if necessary (Ref. 72-00-00, SERVICING).
Perform required ground checks (Ref. 71-00-00 ADJUSTMENT/TEST).

procedure.title: General
procedure.caution: THE BORESCOPE IS A DELICATE DEVICE; IT IS CONSIDERED VULNERABLE TO SEVERE SHOCKS, TWISTING AND PINCHING. CARE AND ATTENTION MUST BE EXERCISED WHEN HANDLING IT SO AS TO PROLONG ITS SERVICE LIFE.

HEAT CAN SEVERELY DAMAGE FIBERSCOPE. BORESCOPE INSPECTION MUST BE ACCOMPLISHED AFTER ENGINE HAS COOLED TO ACCEPTABLE LEVEL (NORMAL COOL DOWN PERIOD IS 40 MINUTES FROM ENGINE SHUTDOWN). MAXIMUM SUGGESTED WORKING TEMPERATURE IS 66°C (150°F).
procedure.step: The borescope is an optical device that enables an operator to perform visual inspections of the hot section and compressor areas of the engine while the engine remains installed in the airframe or at a ground handling installation, as applicable.
The borescope equipment has the capability to take and store digital photographs on removable media so that a record may be made of the borescope inspection.
Damage may be difficult to estimate through a borescope. It is therefore important that borescope inspection be performed by experienced personnel only.
It is recommended that a compressor wash be performed (Ref. 71-00-00) prior to carrying out a borescope inspection.

Rotation of the HP compressor and HP turbine for borescope inspection and AGB static torque check can be done by removing the AGB centrifugal breather outlet and installing a suitable hand crank with a ½ inch square drive. For AGB static torque check, use a standard torque wrench with ½ inch square drive.
Borescope access to engine components can be achieved as outlined in Table , following:

table.title: Borescope Access Ports (Ref. Fig. ) and Inspection Schedule

subpara.title: Inspection Tables
subpara.para: Tables through show two levels of permissible damage. The first level permits continued operation with no change in the inspection interval. The second interval permits continued operation providing that repeat borescope inspections are performed at a maximum of 400 operating hours.

procedure.title: Inspection (Ref. Fig. and Table )
procedure.step: Insert borescope probe through fan until vane ring is visible.
Examine vane ring (Ref. Table ).
Reposition probe through fan and repeat until all vanes have been examined.
Remove borescope.

row.entry: Any tears or cracks on any surface
Acceptableprovided the dent is notassociated with a bulge at the same location onthe opposite surface
The dent is associated witha bulge at the same location on the opposite surface
Acceptable up to 0.025 in.(0.635 mm) deep.
Deformation is acceptableif less than 0.040 in.(1.016 mm) deep and0.500 in. (12.7 mm) long
Deformation in excess of0.040 in. (1.016 mm) deepand/or 0.500 in. (12.7 mm)long
Acceptable up to 0.010 in.(0.254 mm) deep

procedure.title: Inspection (Ref. Fig. and Table )
procedure.step: Insert borescope probe through fan until vane ring is visible.
Examine vane ring .
Reposition probe and repeat until all vanes have been examined.
Remove borescope.

row.entry: LE: Max. 4 per vane if: -dim. a is less than 0.150 inch (3.8 mm)-dim. b is less than 0.125 inch (3.2 mm),and separated by a minimum of 0.300 inch (7.6 mm).
More than four per vane or/and if dim. a is more than 0.150 inch (3.8 mm), or/and dim. b is more than 0.125 inch (3.2 mm), or/and less than0.300 inch (7.6 mm) apart.
TE: Max. 4 per vaneif dim. a and dim. b are less than 0.050inch (1.3 mm) each, and separated by a minimum of 0.300 inch (7.6 mm).
If either dim a and/or b are more than 0.050 inch (1.3 mm) and/orless than 0.300 inch (7.6 mm) apart.
Airfoil: Max. one per pressure or suction surface 0.020 inch (0.5 mm) deep if not directly opposite each other.
Nicks deeper than 0.020 inch (0.5 mm), or one on each surface directly opposite eachother.
One per vane if dim. a is less than0.250 inch (6.3 mm) and deflection is 0.030 inch (0.8 mm) max.
More than one bent area per vane, or/and deflection more than 0.030 inch (0.8 mm) .

procedure.title: Inspection (Ref. Fig. and Table )
procedure.note: Refer also to Borescope Inspection (Ref. Para. ) and first-stage HP Compressor Blade Inspection (Ref. Para. ).

figure.title: VIGV and First-stage HP Compressor Blades

procedure.step: Remove accessory gearbox breather tube (Ref. Airframe Maintenance Manual).
Insert borescope probe through fan and core stators until VIGV is visible.
Inspect VIGV.
Reposition probe (Ref. Step and ) until all 29 vanes have been inspected.
Remove borescope.
Reinstall AGB breather tube (Ref. Airframe Maintenance Manual).

row.entry: Nicks: Leading and Trailing edge (Areas a)

Maximum of two per vane permitted if:- dim. b is less than 0.150 inch (3.8 mm),-dim. c is less than 0.050 inch (1.3 mm) -nicks are separated by a minimum of 0.200 inch (5.1 mm) and are not within 0.250 inch (6.4 mm) of vane root or tip.

Maximum of two per vane permitted on a maximum of four vanes if:-dim. b is less than 0.200 inch (5.1 mm),- dim. c is less than 0.070 inch (1.8 mm) and nicks are separated by a minimum of 0.200 inch (5.1 mm) and are not within 0.250 inch (6.4 mm) of vane root or tip

More than two nicks per vane or more than four vanes damaged Dim. b is more than 0.200 inch (5.1 mm). Dim. c is more than 0.070 inch (1.8 mm).Nicks occur within 0.250 inch (6.4 mm) of vane root or tip.
Damage within 0.250 inch from the T.E. up to a maximum depth of 0.010 inch.
Damage up to a maximum depth of 0.020 inch.
Nicks or dents in excess of 0.020 inch deep or more than 0.250 inch from the T.E.
Localised shallow nicks or dents is acceptable provided the damage is not directly opposite on the suction and pressure sides and the airfoil is not distorted.
Nicks or dents that are directly opposite on the suction and pressure sides and/or the airfoil is distorted.

entry.note: If damage is more than limits specified, remove engine for repair. If an aircraft must be flown to a facility equipped for engine removal, record the extent of damage and submit this information to Pratt & Whitney Canada. A review of the information may permit P&WC to recommend limited engine operation for purposes of obtaining a flight permission from the operator's regulatory authority.

procedure.title: Inspection (Ref. Fig. and Table )
procedure.note: Refer also to Borescope Inspection (Ref. Para. ) and VIGV Inspection (Ref. Para. ).
procedure.step: Remove accessory gearbox breather tube (Ref. Airframe Maintenance Manual).
Insert borescope probe through fan and core stators. (Ref. Fig. ).
Feed probe through VIGV until First-stage HP compressor blade is visible.
Inspect compressor blade.

ENSURE TIP OF BORESCOPE IS NOT ENGAGED BETWEEN COMPRESSOR BLADES BEFORE ROTATING ENGINE.Rotate engine slowly (using a 1/2 inch square drive wrench inserted through AGB breather outlet) and repeat until all 23 blades have been inspected.
Remove borescope.
Reinstall AGB breather tube (Ref. Airframe Maintenance Manual).

row.entry: Maximum of two per blade if:- dim. a is less than 0.125 inch (3.2 mm), -dim. b is less than 0.050 inch(1.3 mm)-nicks separated by a minimum of 0.200 inch (5.1 mm) and are not within 0.250 inch (6.4 mm) of blade root or 0.300 inch (7.6 mm) of blade tip.

Maximum of two per blade permitted on a maximum of four blades if: -dim. a is less than 0.250 inch (6.4 mm), -dim. b is less than 0.100 inch (2.5 mm) and separated by a minimum of 0.200 inch (5.1 mm) and are not within 0.250 inch (6.4 mm) of blade root or 0.300 inch (7.6 mm) of blade tip.

More than two nicks per blade or morethan four bladesdamaged. Dim. a is more than 0.250 inch (6.4 mm). Dim. b is more than 0.100 inch (2.5 mm). Nicks are within 0.250inch (6.4 mm) of blade root or 0.300 inch (7.6 mm) of blade tip.

Maximum of two per blade permitted if: -dim. c is less than 0.070 inch (1.8 mm), -dim. d is less than 0.020 inch (0.5 mm) and separated by 0.200 inch (5.1 mm) minimum and are not within 0.250 inch (6.4 mm) of blade root.

Maximum of two per blade permitted on a maximum of four blades if: -dim. c is less than 0.150 inch(3.8 mm), -dim. d is less than 0.040 inch (1.0 mm) and separated by a minimum of 0.200 inch (5.1 mm) and are not within 0.250 inch (6.4 mm) of blade root.
More than two nicks per blade or more than four blades damaged. Dim. c ismore than 0.150 inch (3.8 mm). Dim. d is more than 0.040 inch (1.0 mm). Nicks arewithin 0.250 inch(6.4 mm) of blade root.
Surface Damage: Nicks or Dents (Area p)
Permitted to a maximum depth of 0.010 inch (0.025 mm) if damage is not directly opposite on pressure and suction sides of blade.
Damage more than 0.010 inch (0.25 mm) deep or is directly opposite on pressureand suction sides of blade.
Blade Tip Corner Loss: Leading edge
Permitted if:- dim. e is less than 0.100 inch (2.5 mm)- dim. f is less than 0.200 inch (5.0 mm).
Permitted if: -dim. e is less than 0.200 inch (5.0 mm) -dim. f is less than 0.400 inch (10.1 mm).
Dim. e is more than 0.200 inch (5.0 mm) and dim. f is more than 0.400 inch (10.1 mm).
Blade Tip Corner Loss: Trailing edge
Permitted if: - dim. g is less than 0.030 inch (0.7 mm) - dim. h is less than 0.030 inch (0.7 mm).
Permitted if: - dim. g is less than 0.060 inch (1.5 mm) - dim. h is less than 0.060 inch (1.5 mm).
Dim. g more than 0.060 inch (1.5 mm) and dim. h more than 0.060 inch (1.5 mm).

entry.note: If damage is more than limits specified, remove engine for repair. If an aircraft must be flown to a facility equipped for engine removal, record the extent of damage and submit this information to Pratt & Whitney Canada. A review of the information may permit P&WC to recommend limited engine operation for purposes of obtaining flight permission from the operator's regulatory authority.

Rubbing of abradable coating on the HP compressor front case assembly is acceptable provided the engine was not identified as having a performance problem:
Abradable wear is acceptable in the rotor sealing area (i.e run in) (first-stage and second-stage).
Gouges and other surface wear are acceptable provided the parent material is not exposed (first-stage and second-stage).
The abradable may be lifted/flaking provided the parent material is not exposed and the total area is not more than 15 to 10 sq.in. (96 to 64 sq.mm) (first-stage and second-stage). If the limit is exceeded contact P&WC Service Engineering for evaluation and disposition.
No cracks are allowed.

procedure.title: Inspection (Ref. Fig. and Table )
procedure.note: Refer to Borescope Inspection (Ref. Para. ).
procedure.step: If necessary, remove accessory gearbox breather tube (Ref. Airframe Maintenance Manual).
Remove six bolts (1) fastening cover (2) at blanked off LP bleed port. Remove cover (2) and gasket (3), discard gasket.
Install guide tube (PWC61803)with bolts (1) and feed borescope probe through guide tube into third-stage HP compressor vane area.
Position probe such that fourth-stage HP compressor blade can be viewed. It is possible to view blade leading edge only.
Inspect fourth-stage compressor blade.

MAKE SURE TIP OF BORESCOPE IS NOT ENGAGED BETWEEN COMPRESSOR BLADES BEFORE ROTATING ENGINE.Rotate engine slowly (using a ½ inch square drive wrench inserted through accessory gearbox breather outlet) and repeat until all 39 blades have been inspected.
Remove borescope and guide tube.
Install cover (2) with new gasket (3) on LP bleed port, secure cover using six bolts (1). Torque bolts 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.0-4.6 Nm).
Reinstall AGB breather tube (Ref. Airframe Maintenance Manual).

row.entry: Maximum two nicks per blade if: -dim. r is less than 0.060 inch (1.5 mm), - dim. s is less than 0.040 inch (1.0 mm) and nicks are separated by a minimum of 0.200 inch (5.1 mm), and are not within 0.250 inch (6.4 mm) of blade root or 0.125 inch (3.2 mm) of blade tip.

Maximum two nicks per blade on a maximum of four blades if:- dim. r is less than 0.125 inch (3.2 mm),-dim. s is less than 0.080 inch (2.0 mm) and nicks are separated by a minimum of 0.200 inch (5.1 mm) and are not within 0.250 inch (6.4 mm) of blade root or 0.125 inch (3.2 mm) of blade tip.

More than two nicks per blade or more than four blades damaged. Dim. r is more than 0.125 inch (3.2 mm). Dim. s is more than 0.080 inch (2.0 mm). Nicks are closer than 0.250 inch (6.4 mm) from blade root or 0.125 inch (3.2 mm) of blade tip.
Surface Damage: Nicks or Dents (Area q)
Permitted to a maximum depth of 0.010 inch (0.25 mm) if damage is not directly opposite on pressure and suction sides of blade.
Damage more than 0.010 inch (0.25 mm) deep or is directly opposite on pressure and suction sides of blade.
Blade Tip Corner Loss: Leading edge
Dim. t is less than 0.050 inch (1.3 mm) and dim. u is less than 0.050 inch (1.3 mm).
Dim. t is less than 0.100 inch (2.5 mm) and dim. u is less than 0.100 inch (2.5 mm).
Dim. t is more than 0.100 inch (2.5 mm) and dim. u is more than 0.100 inch (2.5 mm)

entry.note: If damage is more than limits specified, remove engine and repair. If an aircraft must be flown to a facility equipped for engine removal, record the extent of damage and submit this information to Pratt & Whitney Canada. A review of the information may permit P&WC to recommend limited engine operation for purposes of obtaining flight permission from the operator's regulatory authority.

Rubbing of abradable coating on the fourth-stage compressor stator assembly is acceptable provided the engine was not identified as having a performance problem:
Abradable wear is acceptable in the rotor sealing area (i.e run in).
Gouges and other surface wear are acceptable provided the parent material is not exposed.
The abradable may be lifted/flaking. If this condition is observed, contact P&WC Service Engineering for evaluation and disposition.
No cracks are allowed.

procedure.title: Borescope Inspection
procedure.note: Refer to Borescope Inspection (Ref. Para. ).
Access to inspect the impeller shroud is gained through the two P2.8 Compressor Bleed Valve ports.
procedure.step: Remove P2.8 compressor bleed valves (Ref. 75-30-01).
Insert borescope through P2.8 compressor bleed valve port into impeller shroud area.
Inspect shroud from leading edge to rear case support flange 360 degrees.
Inspect impeller shroud for cracks. Cracks are not acceptable. Replace shroud if evident.
Remove borescope.
Install P2.8 compressor bleed valves (Ref. 75-30-01).

procedure.title: Inspection (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.note: Refer to Borescope Inspection (Ref. Para. ).
The combustion chamber liner can be inspected at this time.
procedure.step: If necessary, remove accessory gearbox breather tube (Ref. Aircraft Maintenance Manual).
Gain access to igniter plugs (Ref. Aircraft Maintenance Manual).

VOLTAGE OUTPUT OF IGNITION EXCITER IS SUFFICIENT TO CAUSE A LETHAL ELECTRICAL SHOCK. RESIDUAL VOLTAGE IN IGNITION EXCITER MAY BE DANGEROUSLY HIGH. ENSURE IGNITION IS SWITCHED OFF. DISCONNECT INPUT CONNECTOR FIRST (REF. AIRFRAME MAINTENANCE MANUAL) AND ALLOW AT LEAST SIX MINUTES TO ELAPSE BEFORE FURTHER WORK IS ATTEMPTED. DISCONNECT IGNITER CABLES AT EXCITER BEFORE DISCONNECTING AT IGNITER PLUGS. ALWAYS USE INSULATED TOOLS TO REMOVE CABLE COUPLING NUTS. DO NOT TOUCH OUTPUT CONNECTORS OR COUPLING NUTS WITH BARE HANDS. DO NOT LET IGNITION CABLE BRAIDING OR FERRULES ROTATE WHEN TURNING COUPLING NUTS.Disconnect ignition exciter input connector (Ref. Aircraft Maintenance Manual). It is necessary to remove only one igniter plug for borescope access.
Loosen coupling nuts and disconnect ignition cable (1) from ignition exciter (2) and igniter plug (3).
Remove igniter plug (3) and gasket (4).
Examine igniter plug for damage (Ref. 74-10-01).

Feed borescope probe through igniter boss into combustion chamber liner. Manipulate probe until fuel nozzle is visible. Guide tube (PWC43685) may be used to borescope fuel nozzles. Guide tube arrow must be pointing towards the front-top of the engine at an angle of between 45 degrees and 90 degrees.
Inspect fuel nozzle for evidence of: Carbon build-up affecting fuel nozzle operation. Nozzle blockage. Thermal distress.

If any of above conditions are evident, inspect all downstream areas for damage. If no downstream damage is evident, engine may continue in service with a reduced borescope frequency of 50 operating hours.
Repeat procedure until all 24 fuel nozzles have been inspected. Fuel nozzles are line replacable (Ref. 73-10-04).

procedure.title: Borescope Installation/Removal
procedure.note: For engines operating on-condition Hot Section Inspection using ECTM, combustion chamber liners require scheduled borescope inspection. Refer to Chapter 05-20-00, Periodic Inspection.
procedure.step: If necessary, remove accessory gearbox breather tube (Ref. Aircraft Maintenance Manual).
Gain access to igniter plugs (Ref. Aircraft Maintenance Manual).

VOLTAGE OUTPUT OF IGNITION EXCITER IS SUFFICIENT TO CAUSE A LETHAL ELECTRICAL SHOCK. RESIDUAL VOLTAGE IN IGNITION EXCITER MAY BE DANGEROUSLY HIGH. ENSURE IGNITION IS SWITCHED OFF. DISCONNECT INPUT CONNECTOR FIRST (REF. AIRFRAME MAINTENANCE MANUAL) AND ALLOW AT LEAST SIX MINUTES TO ELAPSE BEFORE FURTHER WORK IS ATTEMPTED. DISCONNECT IGNITER CABLES AT EXCITER BEFORE DISCONNECTING AT IGNITER PLUGS. ALWAYS USE INSULATED TOOLS TO REMOVE CABLE COUPLING NUTS. DO NOT TOUCH OUTPUT CONNECTORS OR COUPLING NUTS WITH BARE HANDS. DO NOT ALLOW IGNITION CABLE BRAIDING OR FERRULES TO ROTATE WHEN TURNING COUPLING NUTS.Disconnect ignition exciter input connector (Ref. Aircraft Maintenance Manual). It is necessary to remove only one igniter plug for borescope access.
Loosen coupling nuts and disconnect ignition cable (1, Fig. ) from ignition exciter (2) and igniter plug (3).
Remove igniter plug (3) and gasket (4).
Examine igniter plug for damage (Ref. 74-10-01).

Insert borescope (if available use a 5 mm borescope as this is more rigid and allows operator to manoeuvre it inside the combustion liner) through the igniter plug opening. Feed borescope through and inspect different areas of combustion liner. Guide tube (PWC43685) may be used to borescope the combustion liner. Guide tube arrow must be pointing towards the front-top of the engine at an angle of between 45 degrees and 90 degrees.

procedure.title: Inspection (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: The following conditions are acceptable for continuing service with subsequent borescope inspection at the regular interval: Plasma coating loss. Non-converging cracks on the combustion liner walls. Cracks around fuel nozzles or igniter bosses that do not extend more than 180 degrees. Cooling ring cracks that are not forming a closed pattern. Cracks along the cooling ring seam welds that are less than 6.000 inch long.

The following conditions are acceptable for continuing service with a repeat borescope inspection of affected area(s) at no more than 1200 Flight Hours: SUBSEQUENT BORESCOPE INSPECTIONS MUST BE DONE AT INTERVALS DEPENDING ON THE RATE OF PROGRESSION AND LEVEL OF DETERIORATION SEEN.Converging or open cracks on combustion liner walls. Open cracks on combustion liner wall situated in the area between the igniter and fuel nozzle bosses may affect engine starting characteristics. Engine removal may be required if no lighting occurs or the time to achieve idle speed is too long. Cooling ring seam welds cracks that are longer than 6.000 inches but less than 12.000 inches. Combustion liner wall bulging and/or hot spots. Generalized thumbnail band heavy oxidation and material loss. Up to a maximum of five local heavy oxidation or hot spots associated with material loss creating holes less than 0.225 inch diameter on the inner panel. For reference purposes, the larger of the two rows of cooling holes located on the inner panel are 0.225 inch diameter.

The following conditions are acceptable for continuing service with a repeat borescope inspection of affected area(s) at no more than 400 Flight Hours: Material loss at aft edge of inner liner exit duct lip up to 0.200 inch axial length over any circumferential length and local areas up to 0.500 inch axial length by 0.500 inch circumferential length. Axial cracks that are open and associated with local heavy oxidation at outer ring (fretting area) of the turbine air nozzle segment locating groove (Ref. Fig. ).

The following conditions require engine removal within 100 Flight Hours for the Combustion Liner replacement: Holes in combustion liner walls on area other than inner liner panel or inner liner exit duct lip. Holes in inner liner panel exceeding 0.225 inch diameter. Material loss at aft edge of Inner Liner Exit Duct lip exceeding 0.200 inch axial length over any circumferential length, or 0.500 inch axial length by 0.500 inch circumferential length. Holes in cooling rings caused by material loss due to oxidation/burning, cracks opening or crack converging forming a closed pattern. Cooling ring seam welds cracks that are longer than 12.000 inches. Generalized thumbnail band heavy oxidation and material loss associated with multiple cracks propagating into the cooling ring.

procedure.title: Borescope Installation/Removal
procedure.note: Refer to Borescope Inspection (Ref. Para. ).
procedure.step: If necessary, remove accessory gearbox breather tube (Ref. Aircraft Maintenance Manual).
Gain access to igniter plugs (Ref. Aircraft Maintenance Manual).

VOLTAGE OUTPUT OF IGNITION EXCITER IS SUFFICIENT TO CAUSE A LETHAL ELECTRICAL SHOCK. RESIDUAL VOLTAGE IN IGNITION EXCITER MAY BE DANGEROUSLY HIGH. ENSURE IGNITION IS SWITCHED OFF. DISCONNECT INPUT CONNECTOR FIRST (REF. AIRFRAME MAINTENANCE MANUAL) AND ALLOW AT LEAST SIX MINUTES TO ELAPSE BEFORE FURTHER WORK IS ATTEMPTED. DISCONNECT IGNITER CABLES AT EXCITER BEFORE DISCONNECTING AT IGNITER PLUGS. ALWAYS USE INSULATED TOOLS TO REMOVE CABLE COUPLING NUTS. DO NOT TOUCH OUTPUT CONNECTORS OR COUPLING NUTS WITH BARE HANDS. DO NOT ALLOW IGNITION CABLE BRAIDING OR FERRULES TO ROTATE WHEN TURNING COUPLING NUTS.Disconnect ignition exciter input connector (Ref. Aircraft Maintenance Manual). It is necessary to remove only one igniter plug for borescope access.
Loosen coupling nuts and disconnect ignition cable (1, Fig. ) from ignition exciter (2) and igniter plug (3).
Remove igniter plug (3) and gasket (4).
Examine igniter plug for damage (Ref. 74-10-01).
Install guide tube (PWC43685) in either igniter plug boss. The guide tube arrow must be pointing toward the front of the engine and down at an angle of between 30 degrees and 45 degrees.
Feed borescope through guide tube until first-stage HP turbine vane segment can be viewed.
To inspect as many vanes as possible, guide the borescope in front of the vane leading edges and push it in CW direction.
Inspect the leading edge then turn the borescope tip and go in between airfoils and inspect the convex and concave surfaces and adjacent turbine shroud.
Repeat the inspection procedure for the next airfoil and shroud.
Remove borescope and guide tube.

procedure.title: Inspection (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: The following conditions are acceptable for continuing service with subsequent borescope inspection at the regular interval: Non-converging cracks on vane airfoil, outer and inner ring. Suction surface airfoil cracks with no airfoil wall lifting. Open cracks at trailing edge of the outer and inner ring. Leading edge erosion with no material loss.

The following conditions are acceptable for continuing service with a repeat borescope inspection of affected area(s) at no more than 200 Flight Hours: SUBSEQUENT BORESCOPE INSPECTIONS MUST BE DONE AT INTERVALS DEPENDING ON THE RATE OF PROGRESSION AND LEVEL OF DETERIORATION SEEN.Converging cracks, multi-pronged cracks, open cracks and/or cracks forming a circular pattern. Suction surface airfoil cracks with signs of airfoil wall lifting, but no opening. Localized heavy oxidation and/or erosion with material loss that is not exposing the inner vane cavity. Localized heavy oxidation and/or erosion with material loss on the outer and inner ring at separation between vane segments.

The following conditions require engine removal within 100 Flight Hours for the First-stage HP Turbine Vane replacement: Holes in vane airfoil exposing the inner cavity. Suction surface airfoil cracks with airfoil wall lifting, creating an opening. Loss of a section of vane airfoil and inner or outer platform trailing edge. Heavy oxidation and/or erosion with material loss over the whole length of the inner and/or outer platform at the separation area between two adjacent vane segments. A hole and/or heavy oxidation on one or two adjacent First-stage HP Turbine Vane airfoils may be caused by a deteriorated fuel nozzle. It is recommended that the fuel nozzle set is inspected during the following engine shop visit.

procedure.title: Inspection (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: The following conditions are acceptable for continuing service with subsequent borescope inspection at the regular interval: Erosion and/or oxidation of shroud segment inner surface. Cracks at inner surface. Erosion and/or oxidation of shroud segment at the separation between two adjacent segments that is less than 0.250 inch wide and 0.500 inch long. Curling or lifting of shroud segment edges that is less than 0.250 inch wide and 0.500 inch long.

The following conditions require engine removal within 100 Flight Hours for the First-stage HP Turbine segment replacement: Holes in the shroud segment inner surface caused by heavy oxidation and cracking. Erosion and/or oxidation of shroud segment at the separation between two adjacent segments that is more than 0.250 inch wide and 0.500 inch long.

procedure.title: Borescope Installation/Removal
procedure.caution: HEAT CAN SEVERELY DAMAGE FIBERSCOPE. BORESCOPE INSPECTION MUST BE DONE AFTER ENGINE HAS COOLED TO ACCEPTABLE LEVEL. NORMAL COOL DOWN PERIOD IS 40 MINUTES FROM ENGINE SHUTDOWN. MAXIMUM SUGGESTED WORKING TEMPERATURE OF ENGINE IS 66°C (150°F).
procedure.note: Refer to Borescope Inspection (Ref. Para. ).
procedure.step: If necessary, remove accessory gearbox breather tube (Ref. Aircraft Maintenance Manual).
Gain access to igniter plugs (Ref. Aircraft Maintenance Manual).

VOLTAGE OUTPUT OF IGNITION EXCITER IS SUFFICIENT TO CAUSE A LETHAL ELECTRICAL SHOCK. RESIDUAL VOLTAGE IN IGNITION EXCITER MAY BE DANGEROUSLY HIGH. ENSURE IGNITION IS SWITCHED OFF. DISCONNECT INPUT CONNECTOR FIRST (REF. AIRFRAME MAINTENANCE MANUAL) AND ALLOW AT LEAST SIX MINUTES TO ELAPSE BEFORE FURTHER WORK IS ATTEMPTED. DISCONNECT IGNITER CABLES AT EXCITER BEFORE DISCONNECTING AT IGNITER PLUGS. ALWAYS USE INSULATED TOOLS TO REMOVE CABLE COUPLING NUTS. DO NOT TOUCH OUTPUT CONNECTORS OR COUPLING NUTS WITH BARE HANDS. DO NOT ALLOW IGNITION CABLE BRAIDING OR FERRULES TO ROTATE WHEN TURNING COUPLING NUTS.Disconnect both ignition exciter input connectors (Ref. Aircraft Maintenance Manual).
Loosen coupling nuts and disconnect ignition cable (1, Fig. ) from ignition exciter (2) and igniter plug (3).
Remove igniter plug (3) and gasket (4).
Examine igniter plug for damage (Ref. 74-10-01).
Install guide tube (PWC43685) in either igniter plug boss. Guide tube arrow must be pointing forward at an angle of about 10 degrees to 20 degrees up.
Feed borescope through vane until first-stage HP turbine blade can be viewed.

MAKE SURE TIP OF BORESCOPE IS NOT ENGAGED BETWEEN TURBINE BLADES BEFORE ROTATING ENGINE.Rotate engine slowly (using a ½ inch square drive wrench inserted through accessory gearbox breather outlet) and repeat until all 45 blades have been inspected.

If borescope inspection is conducted without P&WC assistance; Annotate details of first-stage HPT Blade/L-Seal borescope inspection results and forward to P&WC, Attention: customerhelpdesk@pwc.ca. Provide photographic inspection records of the following and forward to P&WC, Attention: customerhelpdesk@pwc.ca:
All the first-stage HPT blades (pressure and suction sides).
L-seal at each blade platform gap.
The general condition of the first-stage HPT vane, as viewed through the guide tube.
Remove borescope and guide tube.

procedure.title: Inspection of HP Turbine L Seal (Ref. Figs. , and )

figure.title: Front Cover, L Seal and HP Turbine Rotor
Positioning of the L Seal - Acceptable
Positioning of the L Seal - Unacceptable (Shifted)

procedure.note: To view the L seal, use the Everest Digital borescope (or equivalent from another manufacturer) fitted with a side viewing lens.
procedure.step: Feed borescope through the HP turbine vane until the first-stage HP turbine blade platform can be viewed.

MAKE SURE TIP OF THE BORESCOPE IS NOT ENGAGED BETWEEN THE TURBINE BLADES BEFORE ROTATING ENGINE.Rotate the engine slowly (using a ½ inch square drive wrench inserted through accessory gearbox breather outlet) and repeat until the full circumference of the blade platform has been inspected.

Inspect the (25104) L seal as follows: The L seal should be visible through the gap between the HP Turbine first-stage blade platforms and held in place on the front face of the HP turbine first-stage rotor by the front cover plate (Ref. Fig. ). It is acceptable for the L seal to be positioned so that the forward edge of the seal is flush with the forward edge of the HP turbine first-stage blade platforms (Ref. Fig. ). It is unacceptable for the forward edge of the L seal to protrude forward of the HP turbine blade platforms at any position around the circumference of the rotor. Remove the engine from service within 50 flight hours. (Ref. Fig. ). It is unacceptable for the L seal to have visible cracks or a missing section. Remove the engine from service.

procedure.title: Inspection of Airfoil Trailing Edge (TE) (Ref. Fig. and )
procedure.step: Inspect the 25104 first-stage HP turbine blade airfoil, pressure side, at the TE close to the platform. Record damage observed on worst affected airfoil. Repeat the borescope inspection of the affected area within 50 flight hours if a crack starting at the TE, but not extending past the cooling air ejection slots, is found. Remove the engine immediately if the crack is extending beyond the TE cooling air ejection slots on the pressure face wall.

procedure.title: Inspection of All Other Areas (Ref. Fig. , , , and )
procedure.step: The following conditions are acceptable for continuing service with subsequent borescope inspection at the regular interval: Non-converging cracks at blade tip. Oxidation and/or rubbing at blade tip with no material loss. Leading edge and/or airfoil coating loss and oxidation with no material loss. Leading edge tip erosion. Platform blade cracks (suction side) not extending into the filet radius. Trailing edge platform oxidation with no measurable material loss.

The following conditions are acceptable for continuing service with a repeat borescope inspection of affected area(s) at no more than 200 Flight Hours or 200 Cycles, whichever occurs first (Ref. Fig. ).
SUBSEQUENT BORESCOPE INSPECTIONS MUST BE DONE AT INTERVALS DEPENDING ON THE RATE OF PROGRESSION AND LEVEL OF DETERIORATION SEEN.Leading edge coating loss (25104 blades only) heavy oxidation associated with material loss not exposing the blade inner cavity if the cooling holes in the affected area are not obstructed. Open tip cracks, heavy oxidation and/or erosion with material loss that is not exposing the blade inner cavity. 25104 blades: Local coating loss and oxidation on pressure surface, usually starting at the tip with a V shape and centered on the vertical row of cooling holes, without base material loss and cooling holes distortion and/or partial blockage. Platform cracks extending into the blade airfoil up to, but not exceeding, the level of the lowest leading edge cooling hole. Trailing edge platform oxidation with material loss not exceeding 0.2 inch from the edge of the platform. 25104 blades: vertical cracks linking up to three of the cooling holes in the vertical row of cooling holes.

The following conditions are acceptable for continuing in service with a repeat borescope inspection of affected area(s) at no more than 100 Flight Hours or 100 Cycles, whichever occurs first. (Ref. Figs. and ): 25104 blades (Ref. Fig.): Leading edge local coating loss and heavy oxidation associated with cooling hole distortion and/or partial blockage and material loss that does not expose the blade inner cavity. 25104 blades: Local coating loss and heavy oxidation on pressure surface, usually starting at the tip with a "V" shape and centered on the vertical row of cooling holes, with erosion and base material loss and cooling holes distortion and/or partial blockage. 25104 blades: Axial cracks less than 0.030 inch in length that originate at one of the cooling holes in the vertical row and propagate towards the leading edge. Cracks may be on either the pressure side or the suction side, but not both sides. 25104 blades: Vertical cracks linking four or more of the cooling holes in the vertical row of cooling holes.

25175 blades (Ref. Fig. ): the following damage is acceptable for continuing in service with a repeat borescope inspection of the affected area(s) at no more than 100 Hours or 100 Cycles, whichever occurs first, up to a maximum of 800 hours or cycles since the initial finding: airfoil pressure side radial crack less than 0.400 inch in length which originates near the bottom of the blade, less than 0.400 inch from the blade platform, and which propagates toward the blade tip.

The following conditions are acceptable for continuing in service with a repeat borescope inspection of affected area(s) at no more than 50 Cycles or Hours, whichever occurs first: 25104 blades: Leading edge heavy oxidation associated with material loss that is exposing the blade inner cavity, if there are no cracks in the affected area. 25104 blades: Axial cracks less than 0.050 inch on either the airfoil pressure or suction side that originate at one of the cooling holes in the vertical row and propagate towards the leading edge. Cracks may be on either the pressure side or the suction side, but not both sides.

The following conditions require engine removal within 50 Flight Hours for the First-stage HP Turbine Blade replacement: 25104: Leading edge heavy oxidation associated with material loss that is exposing the blade inner cavity. Open tip cracks, heavy oxidation and/or erosion with material loss that is exposing the blade inner cavity. Holes in other areas of blade airfoil exposing the blade inner cavity. Platform cracks extending into airfoil exceeding the level of the lowest leading edge cooling hole. Platform material missing at the leading edge side or exceeding 0.2 inch at trailing edge side.

The following conditions require immediate engine removal (Ref. Fig. ): Axial cracks on the airfoil originating at the cooling holes, that exceed 0.050 inch. Axial cracks of any length on the airfoil, originating at the cooling holes on both the pressure and suction side. Blades with airfoil sections missing. 25104 blades: LE hole associated with airfoil section axial crack on either pressure or suction side. 25175 blades with pressure side damage as follows:
Radial crack exceeding 0.400 inch in length or extending to any edge of the airfoil.
Displaced material or surface lifts creating a step on the airfoil.
Loss of blade material exposing the core cavity.
Converging or branching cracks.

figure.title: First-stage HP Turbine Blade - TE Inspection
First-stage HPT Blades - Pre/Post SB25104 Differences
First-stage HP Turbine Blade - Inspection of All Areas
First-stage HP Turbine Blade - Remove Engine Immediately
First-stage HP Turbine Blade - Borescope Within 100 Hours
First-stage HP Turbine Blade - Borescope Within 200 Hours

procedure.title: Borescope Blanking Plug Removal (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.note: Refer to Borescope Inspection (Ref. Para. ).
procedure.step: If necessary, remove accessory gearbox breather tube (Ref. Aircraft Maintenance Manual).

BEFORE REMOVING BOLTS (1), LUBRICATE THREADS FOR A MINIMUM OF 20 MINUTES WITH PENETRATING OIL (PWC05-076). DO NOT USE WD-40. DO NOT USE TOO MUCH FORCE TO ROTATE THE BOLTS, BACK OFF BOLTS BY A QUARTER TURN FREQUENTLY DURING REMOVAL.Remove two bolts (1, Fig. ) securing borescope blanking plug (2) to LP turbine case.
Remove blanking plug (2), remove and discard seal ring (3).
Install guide tube (PWC62363).
Insert borescope through guide tube and position probe such that Second-stage HP turbine blade can be viewed.
Inspect Second-stage HP turbine blade.

MAKE SURE TIP OF BORESCOPE IS NOT ENGAGED BETWEEN TURBINE BLADES BEFORE ROTATING ENGINE.Rotate engine slowly (using a ½ inch square drive wrench inserted through accessory gearbox breather outlet) and repeat until all 45 blades have been inspected.
Feed probe through Third-stage LP turbine vane until Third-stage LP turbine blade is visible.
Inspect Third-stage LP turbine blade (Ref. Table ).
MAKE SURE TIP OF BORESCOPE IS NOT ENGAGED BETWEEN FIFTH-STAGE VANES BEFORE ROTATING LP SHAFT (FAN). Rotate LP shaft (fan) slowly and repeat until all 76 blades have been inspected.
Install new seal ring (3) on blanking plug (2).
Install blanking plug (2) in LP turbine case.
Apply a light coat of antiseize compound (PWC06-009) on bolts (1) and secure blanking plug (2). Torque bolts 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.0-4.6 Nm).
Reinstall AGB breather tube (Ref. A.M.M.).

procedure.title: Inspection (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: The following conditions are acceptable for continuing service with subsequent borescope inspection at the regular interval: Oxidation and/or rubbing at blade tip. Localized leading edge and/or airfoil coating loss.

The following conditions are acceptable for continuing service with a repeat borescope inspection of affected area(s) at not more than 1200 Flight Hours: SUBSEQUENT BORESCOPE INSPECTIONS MUST BE DONE AT INTERVALS DEPENDING ON THE RATE OF PROGRESSION AND LEVEL OF DETERIORATION SEEN.Leading edge heavey oxidation associated with material loss. Tip cracks, heavy oxidation and/or erosion associated with material loss. Blade airfoil blister caused corrosion/sulfidation.

The following conditions require engine removal within 50 Flight Hours for the Second-stage HP Turbine Blade replacement: Cracks at the airfoil trailing edge. Loss of blade trailing edge tip. Tip open cracks, heavy oxidation and/or erosion with material loss that is exposing the blade inner cavity.

procedure.title: Inspection (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: The following conditions are acceptable for continuing service with subsequent borescope inspection at the regular interval: Rubbing, erosion and/or oxidation of shroud segment inner surface.

The following conditions require engine removal in not more than 1200 Flight Hours for the Second-stage HP Turbine segment replacement: SUBSEQUENT BORESCOPE INSPECTIONS MUST BE DONE AT INTERVALS DEPENDING ON THE RATE OF PROGRESSION AND LEVEL OF DETERIORATION SEEN.Heavy erosion and/or oxidation of shroud segment leading edge associated with material loss and/or cracks.

procedure.title: Inspection (Ref. Fig. )

figure.title: Second-stage HP Turbine Vane Ring Inspection

procedure.step: The following conditions are acceptable for continuing service with subsequent borescope inspection at the regular interval: Non-converging cracks on vane airfoil, outer and inner ring. Leading edge cracks with localized erosion/oxidation and material loss. The above conditions may be repaired.

The following conditions are acceptable for continuing service with a repeat borescope inspection of affected area(s) in not more than 1200 Flight Hours: SUBSEQUENT BORESCOPE INSPECTIONS MUST BE DONE AT INTERVALS DEPENDING ON THE RATE OF PROGRESSION AND LEVEL OF DETERIORATION SEEN.Converging cracks, multi-pronged cracks, open cracks and/or delamination with minor material loss at the trailing edge cooling holes. Generalized heavy oxidation and/or erosion with material loss along the leading edge. open cracks that do not span the entire width of the inner and/or outer ring.

The following conditions require engine removal within 100 Flight Hours for the Second-stage HP Turbine Vane Ring replacement: Holes in vane airfoil exposing the inner cavity. Open cracks spanning the entire width of the inner and/or outer ring. Loss of a section of vane airfoil trailing edge.

procedure.title: Borescope Installation/Removal
procedure.note: Refer to Borescope Inspection (Ref. Para. ).
Access to inspect Fifth-stage Vane is through Turbine Exhaust.
procedure.step: If necessary, remove accessory gearbox breather tube (Ref. Aircraft Maintenance Manual).

BEFORE REMOVING BOLTS (1), LUBRICATE THREADS FOR A MINIMUM OF 20 MINUTES WITH PENETRATING OIL (PWC05-076). DO NOT USE WD-40. DO NOT USE TOO MUCH FORCE TO ROTATE THE BOLTS, BACK OFF BOLTS BY A QUARTER TURN FREQUENTLY DURING REMOVAL.Remove two bolts (1, Fig. ) securing borescope blanking plug (2) to LP turbine case.
Remove blanking plug (2), remove and discard seal ring (3).
Install guide tube (PWC62363).
Insert borescope through guide tube. Adjust guide tube and borescope probe position such that Third-stage LP turbine vane can be viewed. Repeat until all LP vane airfoils are inspected.
Inspect Third-stage LP turbine vane.
Reposition probe and inspect as many vanes as possible.
Install new seal ring (3) on blanking plug (2).
Install blanking plug (2) in LP turbine case.
Apply a light coat of antiseize compound (PWC06-009) on bolts (1) and secure blanking plug (2). Torque bolts 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.0-4.6 Nm).
Reinstall AGB breather tube (Ref. A.M.M.).

procedure.title: Inspection of Vanes (Ref. Fig. and Table )
procedure.step: Inspect Vanes as follows:

row.entry: Acceptable Limits Continue In Service with no additional inspection
Acceptable LimitsContinue in Service with additional inspection at or before 1200 flight hours.
Remove engine for component replacement within 100 flight hours.
Nicks and dents up to 0.060 inch (1.5 mm deep)
Nicks and dents deeper than 0.060 inch (1.5 mm).
Multiple cracks less than 0.080 inch (2.0 mm) long. Oner crack per airfoil less than 0.120 inch (3.0 mm) long.
Converging cracks. More than one crack per airfoil longer than 0.080 inch (2.0 mm). Cracks longer than 0.120 inch (3.0 mm).
Third-stage Vane only: One crack per airfoil, adjacent to the thermocouple, location, max. 8 per vane, less than 0.300 inch (7.6 mm) long.
Third-stage Vane only: One crack per airfoil, adjacent to the thermocouple location, max. 8 per vane, less than 0.400 inch (10.2 mm) long.
Third-stage Vane only: More than 8 cracks or cracks longer than 0.400 inch (10.2 mm) long.
Nicks and dents up to 0.030 inch (0.76 m) deep.
Nicks and dents deeper than 0.030 inch (0.76 mm).
Multiple cracks less than 0.200 inch (5.1 mm) long. One crack per airfoil less than 0.300 inch (7.6 mm) long.
Multiple cracks less than 0.300 inch (7.6 mm) long. One crack per airfoil less than 0.400 inch (10.2 mm) long.
Converging cracks. More than one crack per airfoil longer than 0.300 inch (7.6 mm). Cracks longer 0.400 inch (10.2 mm) long.
Max. 12 bends per vane ring to a max. length of 25% of trailing edge and a max. deflection of 0.060 inch (1.5 mm).
More than 12 bends per vane ring or longer than 25% of trailing edge or deflection larger than 0.060 inch (1.5 mm).
One tear per airfoil less than 0.100 inch (2.5 mm) long.
More than one tear per airfoil or longer than 0.100 inch (2.5 mm).
Max. 2 cracks per airfoil less than 0.100 inch (2.5 mm) long.
Max. 3 cracks per airfoil less than 0.150 inch (3.8 mm) long.
More than 3 cracks per airfoil or longer than 0.150 inch (3.8 mm).
Cracks less than 0.200 inch (5.1 mm) long. 12 cracks per vane ring less than 0.300 ) (7.6 mm) long.
One crack per airfoil less than 0.250 inch (6.4 mm) long.
Converging cracks. More than 12 cracks longer than 0.250 inch (6.4 mm). Cracks longer than 0.300 inch (7.6 mm).

Multiple cracks less than 0.120 inch (3.0 mm) long. Cracks less than 0.200 inch (5.1 mm) long.Max. 12 cracks per vane ring less than 0.300 inch (7.6 mm) long, provided there is max. one crack between two airfoils.

Multiple cracks less than 0.250 inch (6.4 mm) long. Cracks less than 0.300 inch (7.6 mm) long.Max. 8 cracks per vane ring less than 0.400 inch (10.2 mm) long, provided there is max. one cracks between two airfoils.
Converging cracks. Multiple cracks longer than 0.250 inch (6.4 mm).More than 8 cracks longer than 0.300 inch (7.6 mm). Cracks longer than 0.400 inch (10.2 mm).
Max. 12 horse shoe cracks per vane ring less than 0.300 inch (7.6 mm).
More than 12 horse shoe cracks per vane ring longer than 0.200 inch (5.1 mm) or horse show cracks longer than 0.300 inch (7.6 mm).

Multiple axial cracks & horse shoe cracks less than 0.5 inch (12.7 mm) long.One axial crack spanning the entire inner drum width that may extend into airfoil Area 8.Circumferential cracks up to 0.160 inch (4.1 mm).
Open cracks.Cracks causing a step. Converging cracks.

Maximum of 15 axial cracks per vane ring irrespective of length provided:1. Cracks do not extend outside of Area 7 on the inner shroud.2. Only two cracks separated by a minimum of 3 airfoils are reaching the T.E. .3. Cracks extending into airfoil do not exceed Area 8.
Open cracks.Cracks causing a step. Converging cracks.
Vane airfoil (surface protection at Third and Fourth-stage only). NOTE: Sulfidation appears as a green to pale blue color
Slight discoloration and local loss of coating.Local pitting.
Sulfidation over less than 40% of airfoil surface, provided there are no blisters or loss of basic material.
Sulfidation over more than 40% of airfoil surface, or with blisters/loss of basic material.

procedure.title: Borescope Installation/Removal
procedure.note: Refer to Borescope Inspection (Ref. Para. ).
Access to inspect Fifth-stage Blades is through Turbine Exhaust.
procedure.step: If necessary, remove accessory gearbox breather tube (Ref. Aircraft Maintenance Manual).

BEFORE REMOVING BOLTS (1), LUBRICATE THREADS FOR A MINIMUM OF 20 MINUTES WITH PENETRATING OIL (PWC05-076). DO NOT USE WD-40. DO NOT USE TOO MUCH FORCE TO ROTATE THE BOLTS, BACK OFF BOLTS BY A QUARTER TURN FREQUENTLY DURING REMOVAL.Remove two bolts (1, Fig. ) securing borescope blanking plug (2) to LP turbine case.
Remove blanking plug (2), remove and discard seal ring (3).

MAKE SURE TIP OF BORESCOPE IS NOT ENGAGED BETWEEN TURBINE BLADES BEFORE ROTATING ENGINE.Insert borescope through access port, through Third-stage LP turbine vane until Third-stage LP turbine blade is visible.
MAKE SURE TIP OF BORESCOPE IS NOT ENGAGED BETWEEN FIFTH-STAGE VANES BEFORE ROTATING LP SHAFT (FAN). Rotate LP shaft (fan) slowly and repeat until all 76 blades have been inspected.
Install new seal ring (3) on blanking plug (2).
Apply a light coat of antiseize compound (PWC06-009) on bolts (1) and secure blanking plug (2). Torque bolts 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.0-4.6 Nm).
Reinstall AGB breather tube (Ref. A.M.M.).

procedure.title: LP Turbine Blades Inspection (Ref. Fig. and Table )
procedure.step: Inspect LP Blades as follows:

row.entry: Acceptable Limits Continue In Service with inspection at the regular interval.
Acceptable LimitsContinue in Service with additional inspection at or before 1200 flight hours.
Remove engine for component replacement within 50 flight hours.
Cracks ae not permitted, except in areas 1 and 2 (see below)
Local erosion and oxidation without affecting parent material.
Local leading edge erosion and oxidation associated with minor parent material loss.
Heavy or generalized erosion and oxidation associated with parent material loss.
Slight discoloration and local loss of coating.
Sulfidation over less than 40% of airfoil surface, provided there are no blisters or loss of basic material.
Sulfidation over more than 40% of airfoil surface, or with blisters/loss of basic material.
One crack per blade less than 0.040 inch (1.0 mm) long, provided not more than 5 blades are affected.
More than one crack per blade less than 0.040 inch (1.0 mm) long, provided not more than 5 blades are affected.
Nicks and dents less than 0.010 inch (0.25 mm) deep.
Nicks and dents deeper than 0.010 inch (0.25 mm).
One bend on the trailing edge to a max length of 25% of trailing edge and a max deflection of 0.015 inch (0.35 mm), provided not more than 5 blades are affected.
More than one bend on the trailing edge or longer than 25% of trailing edge or a deflection of more than 0.015 inch (0.35 mm) or more than 5 blades affected.
Nicks and dents are not permitted.
Nicks and dents less than 0.005 inch (0.13 mm) deep.
Nicks and dents deeper than 0.005 inch (0.13 mm).

procedure.title: Low Utilization Inspection
procedure.note: The category 1 and 6 Service Bulletins must be considered for incorporation when access permits it.
Do not disassemble sub-assemblies unless indicated in the workscope.
procedure.step: DELETED.
DELETED.

The Low Utilization Inspection (LUI) must be performed as per the following instructions: Do an engine internal wash (Ref. 71-00-00, POWER PLANT - CLEANING). Do a power assurance test (Ref. 71-00-00, POWER PLANT - ADJUSTMENT/TEST). Inspect oil filter content (Ref. 79-20-01, OIL FILTER AND HOUSING - MAINTENANCE PRACTICES). Inspect LP compressor (Ref. 72-30-01, LP COMPRESSOR - INSPECTION) inlet cone, fan blades, fan case, inner and outer vane ring. Remove compressor inlet cone and fan assembly (Ref. 72-30-01, LP COMPRESSOR - REMOVAL/INSTALLATION). Remove compressor inlet vane (Ref. 72-30-01, LP COMPRESSOR - REMOVAL/INSTALLATION). Check intermediate case for corrosion (Ref. 72-30-01, LP COMPRESSOR - INSPECTION). Inspect variable inlet guide vane (Ref. 72-00-00, ENGINE, GENERAL - INSPECTION). Inspect first-stage HP compressor blades (Ref. 72-00-00, ENGINE, GENERAL - INSPECTION). Inspect fourth-stage HP compressor blades (Ref. 72-00-00, ENGINE, GENERAL - INSPECTION). Inspect and clean compressor bleed valve (Ref. 75-30-01, COMPRESSOR BLEED VALVES - MAINTENANCE PRACTICES). Check variable inlet guide vane (VIGV) rigging (Ref. 75-30-04, VIGV ACTUATOR - MAINTENANCE PRACTICES). Inspect combustion chamber liner (Ref. 72-00-00, ENGINE, GENERAL - INSPECTION). Inspect first, second stage HP turbine blades and vanes (Ref. 72-00-00, ENGINE, GENERAL - INSPECTION). Inspect third, fifth stage LP turbine blades and vanes (Ref. 72-00-00, ENGINE, GENERAL - INSPECTION). Inspect fuel nozzle (Ref. 72-00-00, ENGINE, GENERAL - INSPECTION). Check the continuity resistance of T4.5 system (Ref. 77-20-01, T4.5 THERMOCOUPLES - MAINTENANCE PRACTICES). Check security of connections inside T4.5 terminal box (Ref. 77-20-01, T4.5 THERMOCOUPLES - MAINTENANCE PRACTICES). Check for fuel and oil leak externally and at drains. Remove and check chip detector for debris (Ref. 72-00-00, ENGINE, GENERAL - INSPECTION) and (Ref. 79-30-01, CHIP DETECTOR - MAINTENANCE PRACTICES). Inspect chip detector (Ref. 79-30-01, CHIP DETECTOR - MAINTENANCE PRACTICES). Inspect oil filter content for foreign matter and damage (Ref. 79-20-01, OIL FILTER AND HOUSING - MAINTENANCE PRACTICES). Inspect fuel filter (Ref. 73-10-03, FUEL FILTER AND FUEL WASTE EJECTOR - MAINTENANCE PRACTICES). Clean all wiring harness connectors (Ref. 70-00-00, STANDARD PRACTICES - CLEANING). Check for security of all wiring harness, clamps and brackets, and for evidence of wear, chaffing, cracks and corrosion (Ref. 77-20-01, T4.5 THERMOCOUPLES - MAINTENANCE PRACTICES). Check for security of tube connections, clamps and brackets, and for evidence of wear, chaffing, cracks and corrosion (Ref. 70-00-00, STANDARD PRACTICES - CLEANING).
